body: @Charlieface thanks for raising this and for the analysis - this all makes sense ðŸ‘

issue.title: Fix set operation precedence issues

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
Fixes #36105
Fixes #36112

Thanks to @Charlieface for reporting #36105 and also suggesting the right fix.

body:
@roji Thanks for handling this so quickly.

Now that I think about, it's still not quite correct, as it doesn't take into account `UNION ALL` (as well as `INTERSECT ALL` which is allowed on Postgres). For example:
```cs
a.Concat(b.Union(c))
```
gets
```sql
SELECT id
FROM Tests
UNION ALL
SELECT id
FROM Tests
UNION
SELECT Id
FROM Tests
```
where it should have the second and third parameterized together. You can see the difference in [this fiddle](https://dbfiddle.uk/UFRzfgu2). The same thing applies the other way round, although some cases might be OK due to not having the `ALL` implying `DISTINCT` anyway.

I think we'd need to check that property as well. Something like:
```cs
    && (operand.Tables[0] is ExceptExpression ||
            operand.Tables[0].GetType() != setOperation.GetType()) ||
            operant.Tables[0] is SetOperationBase setOp1 && setOp1.IsDistinct == setOperation.IsDistinct)
```
To be honest it's probably best to make the code more OOP by moving the whole check into the `SetOperationBase` and/or its derived classes.

Good catch, I should have thought about this with a bit more scope too. Submitted #36124 to add the check for distinctness.

> To be honest it's probably best to make the code more OOP by moving the whole check into the SetOperationBase and/or its derived classes.

Not sure this is a good direction: parentheses logic is something that's 100% a SQL generation question, and so is only the concern of QuerySqlGenerator. When working with expression trees, this is often how it works - the expression types themselves tend to be data-only nodes, and the logic is in the pipeline of visitors.

BTW if you're interested in evaluation order and parentheses, check out QuerySqlGenerator.RequiresParentheses() and TryGetOperatorInfo() which it runs on top of. The latter is responsible for determining the precedence of an operator and whether it's associative (or commutative), and the former uses that information to determine whether to generate parentheses or not. But this is all about **scalar** operators, and so does not apply to set operations.

Note also that operator precedence may differ across providers, which is another good reason to keep this logic in the visitor (which can be overridden/customized by providers) rather than more it into the expression types themselves (which are universal).

Anyway... Thanks again for all the good suggestions here and looking forward for more!

rename.from: Nested Except is not parenthesizing correctly
rename.to: Parentheses missing with some set operation combinations

issue.title: [release/9.0] Add missing parentheses for set operations

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
Backports #36110 (see #36139 for identical 9.0 backport PR)
Fixes #36105
Fixes #36112

**Description**
When generating SQL for multiple set operators (UNION, INTERSECT, EXCEPT), EF omitted adding parentheses in certain combinations, leading to the LINQ evaluation order not being preserved in the generated SQL. In addition, the SQLite provider didn't generate parentheses at all, since the SQLite syntax is non-standard and we originally thought no form of parentheses was possible.

**Customer impact**
The missing parentheses could cause the SQL set operators to be evaluated in an incorrect order (compared to the user's specified evaluation order in the LINQ query). This could lead to incorrect results getting returned from the database (data corruption).

**How found**
Reported by a user.

**Regression**
No

**Testing**
Added.

**Risk**
Very low. This is a minimal, targeted fix which only adds parentheses to preserve the LINQ evaluation order. A quirk was added just in case.
